result.title: Objective
result.description: REDUCE LOCAL AND GREENHOUSE GAS (GHG) EMISSIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRANSPORT SYSTEM IN DUSHANBE CITY

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of CO2 emissions reduction resulting from implementation of project pilots

baseline.comment:
2011 estimate:
160,000 tons CO2

target.comment:
About 7% reduction in 2015
About 50% reduction in 2025 (10 years after project completion)

actual.comment:
The data on sales of fuel (petrol, LPG, diesel) has been collected by the data collection expert. Analysis is pending. 2013 estimate calculated in September 2014: 217,345 t Co2eq.
There are no signs of CO2 reduction thus far, although there has probably not be a significant increase, either: 2011 estimate considered as probably too low.
More reliable estimates needed. Final estimates for 2015 are being made based on fuel sales in Dushanbe in 2011-2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
THIS INDICATOR SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE LOGFRAME PER RECOMMENDATION OF MTR
Average daily commute time

baseline.comment: Average daily commute increases nearly 2-fold by 2020

target.comment: Average daily commute time in 2020 limited to 50% below 2006 levels.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: 1. Lower emissions from vehicles in Dushanbe

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of local fuel quality standards for petrol and diesel

baseline.comment: Outdated GOST-based standards of local fuel quality standards for petrol and diesel

target.comment: Tajikistan fuel quality standards for petrol and diesel correspond to international ones

actual.comment: The new technical regulation regarding the fuel standards was adopted by the government of Tajikistan in January 2014. It stipulates that the fuel classed 2 and 3, which are harmful to the environment should be phased out during the next 5 years.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
THIS INDICATOR SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE LOGFRAME PER RECOMMENDATION OF MTR
Specifications for installation and use of natural gas and LPG cylinders in vehicles, where used

baseline.comment: Poor safety record for marshrutkas and fuelling operations

target.comment: Safe and clean vehicle and fuelling operations maintained

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: 2. Increased bus and trolleybus modal shares and speeds

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Share of public transport (trolleybus and bus) modes

baseline.comment:
Modal shares (2011):
As per the MTR the original values WERE REVISED: Trolleybus = from 1.9 to 1.7% Buses = from 9.5 to 9.2%

target.comment:
Modal shares per day(2015):
As per the MTR the original value (for Bus only) WAS REVISED: Trolleybus = 4% Bus = from 20 to 14%

actual.comment: In spite of the new bus lanes implemented, no modal change has been detected yet (in accordance with surveys in May-June 2015). Lack of enforcement of bus lanes and lack of improvement in PT frequencies and punctuality identified as key problems.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Average speed of public transport modes along pilot projects

actual.comment:
Speed on bus lanes measured in May-June 2015:
Trolleybus: 10.5 km/h (Ayni)-15.9 km/h (Sherozi)
Bus: 10.7 km/h (Ayni)-18.7 km/h (Sherozi)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Status of Travel Demand Survey for Dushanbe

baseline.comment: Lack of any updated data on public transport operation in Dushanbe city

target.comment: Completion of the first Travel demand survey in Dushanbe city

actual.comment: 2012 travel demand survey revised to include total number of trips among the 33 zones of the city.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
1. Status of implementation of demonstration project for dedicated bus lanes network project in Dushanbe city
2. Length of dedicated bus lanes network

baseline.comment: Increased road congestion, passengersâ€™ dissatisfaction with long trip time and slow speed of public transport modes and as a result increased use of private vehicles

target.comment:
1. Dedicated lanes for public transport modes (buses and trolleybuses) introduced along a pilot transport corridor in Dushanbe city
2. At least 15 km of dedicated bus lanes

actual.comment: Bus lanes operational on Ayni, Sherozi, Somoni and Sino streets. Total length exceeds 15km.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Status of implementation of new paid parking system

baseline.comment: Inefficient parking control causing traffic congestion and delays to public transport operation in Dushanbe city

target.comment: New parking policy approved

actual.comment:
Implementation of a pilot parking control project (APES) is in progress. The system is expected to be operational in Q3 2015.
Parking policy (and related regulatory changes) still under discussion with local stakeholders

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Status of implementation of revised fare collection system

baseline.comment: Inefficient fare collection system resulting in large scale revenue leakage within the public transport network in Dushanbe city

target.comment: New fare collection policy is in place

actual.comment: Fare policy (and related regulatory changes) still under discussion with local stakeholders

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
1. Status of implementation of demonstration Single Dispatcher Control Center project in Dushanbe city
2. Status of pilot trolleybus route

baseline.comment:
1. Lack of modern Dispatcher Control Centre to ensure public transport fleet management and population dissatisfaction with irregular public transport operation in Dushanbe city
2. Conventional, manual monitoring of the route

target.comment:
1. Single Dispatcher Control Center introduced in Dushanbe city
2. One trolleybus route with 35 trolleys is piloted within the Single Dispatcher Control Centre

actual.comment: SDCC hardware delivered, information panels installed and GPS in all vehicles for lines T-1 and B-3. Testing in progress.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE LOGFRAME

target.comment: Single Dispatcher Control Center introduced in Dushanbe city

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE LOGFRAME

target.comment: One trolleybus route is piloted within the Single Dispatcher Control Centre

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: 3. Integrated land use and urban transport planning at the metropolitan level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Number of trained public authorities involved in public transport sector.
2. Changes in local regulation related to urban transport planning.

baseline.comment:
1. Lack of trained personnel in integrated land use and urban transport planning.
2. Lack of specific construction requirements related to urban transport planning.

target.comment:
1. At least 20 public authorities trained in integrated land use and urban transport planning.
2. Revised construction norms related to urban transport planning approved.

actual.comment:
Completed. No additional training activities conducted in this reporting period.
No revised norms developed or approved in the reporting period.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: 4. Increased walking and cycling modal shares

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Length of pilot cycle lane.
2. Changes in local regulations promoting walking and cycling.

baseline.comment:
1. 0 km
2. No specific regulations.

target.comment:
1. 5km of pilot cycle lane.
2. Walking and cycling facilities to be included in all new road projects.

actual.comment:
Inspection of the pilot cycle lane shows poor design and modest use.
In spite of Mayor's instructions, no walking and cycling facilities have been included in new road projects.
Awareness raising activity on cycling with the Cycling Federation of Tajikistan (20-21 September).

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: 5. Institutional transformation of government, businesses and general public to embrace sustainable transport

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The status of implementation of proposed legal and regulatory changes

baseline.comment: Outdated norms and gaps in public transport related legislation

target.comment:
Adoption of proposed legal or regulatory changes, particularly on:
- Reserved use of Public transport lanes and stops.
- Inspection, control, penalties and enforcement for PT services.

actual.comment: Draft report submitted by national legal expert, following discussion with local stakeholders.

indicator.title: Indicator 2

baseline.comment: Lack of understanding and necessity to promote sustainable transport measures among government bodies and general public

target.comment: Reaching at least 10% of the citizens in Dushanbe with at least one of the communication channels

actual.comment: Safe Road Campaign conducted on 18 June with participation of 25 volunteers who distributed handouts about proper behavior on the roads including pedestrians, drivers and bus passengers. Estimated 10,000 citizens outreached.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of trained public authorities involved in public transport sector

baseline.comment:
1. Poor capacity of involved public authorities on sustainable transport measures (with the focus on suggested project demonstrations on dedicated bus lanes/bicycle lane design and standards as well as on modern Dispatcher control Centre operation and Traffic management.
2. Lack of information on best world practices on sustainable transport management.

target.comment:
1. At least 20 public authorities trained on sustainable transport measures
2.1 At least 20 public authorities strengthened their capacity on sustainable transport management via participation in the International Conference on Sustainable Urban Transport issues to be conducted in Dushanbe city.
2.2 At least 5 foreign participants contribute with best practices at the International Conference.

actual.comment: Training activities concluded in April 2014. No further action expected, except for the professional training of SDCC and APES operators and managers (end 2015).

result.title: Objective
result.description: Globally significant agro-biodiversity (ABD) conservation and adaptation to climate change (CC) are embedded in the national and local agricultural and rural development policies and practices of Tajikistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares of landscape where climate resilient agrobiodiversity conservation is mainstreamed

baseline.comment: Oblast/jamoat plans are not considering climate resilient agrobiodiversity

target.comment:
Oblast/jamoat plans incorporate priority ABD and CC issues
1.5 million hectares in four districts (Shurobod, Rasht, Baljuan and Zerafshan) and 36 sub-districts (Jamoats), of which 9 jamoats covering 150,000 hectares are targeted for project interventions.

actual.comment:
During the reporting period, the project continued and finalized its interventions on introducing the policies of agrobiodiversity conservation in the face of climate change at local level (oblast/district/jamoat levels).
Within the framework of the Small Grants Programme, the project implemented 6 initiatives on establishment of additional new mother gardens on the area of 22 hectares. As for the micro-loan activities, 13.1 ha of fruit gardens were created in the gardens of local farmers. In total, 35.1 hectares have been covered by newly created mother gardens, which means, that after the project completion at least one mother garden will be available at each district to cover needs in agrobiodiversity garderning.
The end of the project target was achieved as 1.5 million hectares, including 36 Jamoats of 7 administrative districts, were directly covered by the project interventions, including dissemination of experience, concluding agreements with Jamoats, offering study tours and implementation of the Small Grants Programme initiatives. Moreover, the project achievements indirectly expanded to the area of 2.5 million hectares as evidenced by 84 homologues sites identified, adaptation techniques applied and disseminated, germplasm exchange enabled, fairs and microfinance activities performed on those areas, etc.
At the institutional level, the issues of conservation and dissemination of locally adapted genetic resources of agrobiodiversity are being regularly introduced into the plans of subordinate organizations of the Ministry of Agriculture, the National Centre on Genetic Resources, the Forestry Agency and the Institute of Agriculture under the Academy of Agricultural Sciences. The achievements of the project were included into the National Development Strategy of the Republic of Tajikistan for the period up to 2030 and the Medium-Term Development Program from 2016 to 2020 as priorities.
At the local level, sustainability of the project achievements and further rational use of agrobiodiversity is ensured through the operational long-term work plans, adopted by each of 42 Jamoats.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Farms in pilot areas have the capacity to implement in situ and ex-situ conservation of climate resilient ABD as means to cope with impacts of CC through implementation of Homologue Approach;

baseline.comment:
Limited local capacity for in-situ and ex-situ conservation of climate resilient agrobiodiversity.
Few ex-situ collections of germplasm as identified through GBIF database

target.comment:
Ex situ and in situ conservation that provides adapted germplasm for crop improvement and climate resilience programmes in Tajikistan and globally
Tajik germplasm used and valued by farms/ communities as means to adapt to climate change

actual.comment:
In 2014-2015 the local farmers’ abilities in in-situ and ex-situ conservation has been strengthened through capacity-building and awareness activities as below:
- 18 workshops and trainings were offered to representatives of local jamoats, farmers, land-users and householders. 825 people become capacitated in applying agrobiodiversity conservation techniques in their daily agricultural activities.
- More than 60 farmers and households from 2 project areas improved their knowledge of adaptation methods.
- 40 beneficiaries from project areas improved their knowledge of the significance of genetic resources and relevant agro-business activities.
As for practical inputs, the database of in-situ habitats of wild genetic resources was made available. It is used as effective instrument for maintaining, rehabilitation and sustainable cultivation of local agrobiodiversity, germplasm exchange, creation of mother nurseries, etc. The database covers the data, gathered from 36 project Jamoats.
By the end of the project, ex-situ and in-situ conservation is ensured through the adapted germplasm of 10 priority fruit and nut species (and their 71 varieties), as well as cereals and leguminous plants. 50 farms/communities within the project areas value Tajik local germplasm and use it to adapt to climate variability. Global germplasm exchange is ensured through relevant exchange programmes, which are executed in partnership with Russia, Norway and Afghanistan.
The Homologue Approach has been successfully implemented. The adaptation homology model, developed for 42 jamoats and 84 homologous sites, ensures 100 years of successful farming and sustainability of genetic resources productiveness in the project domain.
Further sustainability of project achievements will be ensured by the National Strategy on Conservation of Agrobiodiversity in the Face of Climate Change (after its adoption by the Government) - along with direct impact, the Strategy will also create synergies with other relevant governmental programmes and strategies. Alternatively, the instructions and guidelines developed by the project will support practical implementation of ABD practices on the ground (2 instructions on ex-situ conservation of valuable genetic resources, 6 guidelines on cultivation of ABD cereals and leguminous crops, 1 guideline in running small businesses in rural areas, 1 strategy of marketing, 1 market development strategy, 1 communication strategy).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Agro-biodiversity conservation and adaptation to climate change through supportive policy, regulatory and institutional frameworks

indicator.title: Indicator 1

baseline.comment: Enabling environment at national and local level is not conducive for agrobiodiversity conservation and its potential role for climate adaptation and future food security

target.comment: Agro-biodiversity friendly and climate resilient policies and practices embedded into national policy and local development plans contributing to improved agrobiodiversity conservation in the face of climate change in four project areas covering 150,000 ha.;

actual.comment:
By the end of the project, agro-biodiversity conservation agenda is included into national policies and local development plans that contributes to both sustainability of the project achievements and further dissemination of relevant practices.
At the nationwide level, the text of the National Strategy on conservation of Agrobiodiversity in the Face of Climate Change is prepared and translated into 3 languages. The final version of the Strategy incorporates the recommendations and opinions of all participating stakeholders gathered through relevant interagency meetings offered by the project within the reporting period. The text of the Strategy is submitted to the Government for review and approval.
The project also contributed to integrating agrobiodiversity conservation into the state policies. The experiences and achievements of the project were accounted during preparation of the National Development Strategy of the Republic of Tajikistan for the period up to 2030 and the Medium-Term Development Program from 2016 to 2020.
At the local level, plans-agreements with 42 jamoats continue contributing to conservation of agrobiodiversity and development of markets in nine districts. During the period under review, the project carried out continuous monitoring over the implementation progress by gathering and analyzing statistical data, collaborating with the UNDP Area Office in Kulob, developing questionnaires for wide polling in the project jamoats, etc. Along with that, Agrobiodiversity conservation issues are included into development programs of 7 project districts.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Institutional framework in place at the national and local level facilitates implementation of ABD relevant policies, legislation and regulation in 4 pilot areas;

baseline.comment: Lack of climate and crop models prohibit strategic planning and adaptive capacity development in face of climate change and threats to food security.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved capacity for sustaining agro-biodiversity in the face of climate change

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Improved capacity for ex-situ conservation measures of globally significant and climate resilient agrobiodiversity

baseline.comment: Local communities are not aware of implications of climate change and are not working towards the development of adaptive strategies and capacities;

target.comment: Ex situ conservation of globally significant ABD (landraces and CWRs) in gene (e.g. seed) banks and as living collections (in botanic gardens, nurseries, farms) in the case of recalcitrant CWRs, in collaboration with local institutions (including walnut, pistachio, pomegranate, fig, mulberry, apricot and almond)

actual.comment:
In 2014-2015 the project continued and completed its interventions on improving capacity for ex-situ conservation of globally significant and climate resilient agrobiodiversity through the inputs as below:
- Collection nursery garden of the National Republican Center for Genetic Resources was replenished with 6,500 seedlings of adapted fruit varieties on the area of 0,20 ha; this allows further dissemination of genetic resources among households of project areas and homology site collections.
- Wider dissemination of ex-situ conservation practices is ensured by 35,1 hectares of gardens, created and rehabilitated as a part of the Small Grants Program and the Micro-Loan Fund activities. Specifically, 6 initiatives on creating new mother gardens were implemeted on the area of 22 hectares in two pilot areas within the Small Grants Program. Within the framework of the Micro-Loan Funds (revolving funds), 13.1 hectares were covered by newly created and rehabilitated gardens. All seedlings planted in those new gardens were properly grafted and adapted to climate change affects including unfavourable weather conditions, dry seasons, etc
Totally, during its duration the project ensured ex-situ conservation of 50 globally significant recalcitrant landraces and wild relatives (of them 23 cereals and 27 fruits) in seed and nursery gene banks and as living collections in botanic gardens, organized, without limitation, at the National Center for Genetic Resources, Botanic Garden of Kulob, 4 nursery gardens in Danghara, etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improved capacity of farmers in four project areas to design and implement on-farm agrobiodiversity conservation measures as an adaptive capacity to climate risks and variability

baseline.comment:
Lack of socio-ecological resilience to climate variability and shocks;
Negligible national and local capacity to cope with climate risks and variability

target.comment: On-farm conservation of wild relatives and landraces of globally significant ABD in 40 home gardens/farms in 4 project areas.

actual.comment:
By the end of the project, the mission of ensuring conservation of wild relatives and landraces of globally significant agrobiodiversity has been completely completed. Farmers from 50 model farms/communities were capacitated in on-farm conservation practices by using relevant techniques for conservation of 10 priority fruit and nut species (and their 71 varieties), and 6 varieties of cereals and leguminous crops.
Follow-up activities during the reporting period 2014-2015 included monitoring of the achievements and ensuring the inclusion of agrobiodiversity conservation and adaptation measures into developing processes at both jamoat and district levels. Specifically, the monitoring conducted in collaboration with the Forestry Agency in one of the project districts proved that mother gardens of 9 fruit varieties, created on the area of 12 hectares, are in good condition and provide fruits.
The newly established Jamoat Resource Center of the Sarikhosor Jamoat provides advisory support to farmers and households on the issues of agrobiodiversity conservation and market development. Moreover, consultations offered by the project contributed to the new project “Arranging Mother Garden of Collectors’ Genetic Resources” (in-situ on farm), which is implemented by the Jamoat Resource Center of Sarikhosor in cooperation with the UNDP/SGP/GEF.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Farming communities have the capacity to implement the results of homologue approach implemented in 4 project so as to enable the adaptation of their current production practices to current and future climate risks and variability

baseline.comment: No existing community-to-community seed and germplasm exchange programmes based on climate change impacts;

target.comment: Improved capacity of farmers (men/women) in 40 home gardens/farms in 4 pilot sites to participate in implementation of the Homologue Approach and to initialize own germplasm exchanges to cope with future impacts of CC;

actual.comment:
Capacity building of farmers is successfully completed in four project areas. During the period under review, the project continued putting efforts towards strengthening the communities’ capacities in practicing the homologue approach and germplasm exchange.
For instance, more than 90 farmers and representatives of households became more capacitated in the methods of agrobiodiversity conservation through adaptation measures, specifically, the homology modelling. Along with that, useful skills and knowledge of germplasm exchange for business purposes, identification of wild relatives’ genetic resources and applying adaptation techniques were gained by 50 agronomists and farmers from the project areas.
Altogether, during the project duration, 2,083 people from 4 pilot areas, Kulob and Rasht districts become capacitated through 109 relevant workshops and trainings.
To allow germplasm exchange, 15,705 seedlings were planted in 10 project jamoats further to the 84 homology sites identified for 42 jamoats. Particularly, the germplasm exchange of fruit varieties was enabled during seedlings sales exhibitions in Dushanbe and Kulob. More than 5,000 seedlings of fruit varieties adapted to climate variability were presented at those exhibitions, that contributed to the germplasm exchange between local farmers and relevant profits from the sale of local genetic resources. Another example is the exchange of 1,000 seedlings of local fruit genetic resources, that was made by a local farmer as a result of border trade with Afghanistan.
By the end of the project it may be stated, that the germplasm exchange has become a continuous process. Along with such at the local level, global programs of germplasm exchange are being implemented in partnership with Russia, Norway and Afghanistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increased awareness of the importance of conserving CWRs in their natural habitat

baseline.comment: Farmers are permitted to collect CWRs in reserves (IUCN IV) and not considering the long-term conservation of ABD

target.comment: Farmers are capacitated in in-situ conservation of wild relatives of globally significant ABD in its natural habitat (including reserves) in 4 project areas.

actual.comment:
Awareness raising activities on the importance of conservation of wild relatives and practicing environment-friendly agrobiodiversity accompanied the project during its entire duration, and in 2014-2015 were completed by the below:
- More than 70 representatives of national institutions, scientific communities, universities and NGOs improved their capacities in understanding the principles of sustaining agrobiodiversity and adaptation to climate variability based on wild relatives’ genetic resources during the scientific conference in Dushanbe devoted to ecological specifics of biological diversity (13-14 June 2015).
- The issues of traditional methods of agrobiodiversity conservation, housekeeping and receiving benefits from agrobiodiversity products were discussed by more than 50 women and girls from distant mountain localities at the conference devoted to the International Day for Biological Diversity, that was held in the Shuroabad district in cooperation with the NGO “Zan va Zamin”.
- 40 scientists, agronomists and farmers from the project areas became capacitated in the significance of wild relatives in the condition of climate change and received relevant trainings in methods of gathering valuable germplasm for agribusiness.
- 50 pupils and representatives of local administration gained comprehensive understanding of the significance of wild relatives’ in-situ conservation during the conference devoted to the International Day for Biological Diversity (Jamoat of Dashtijum, 24 May 2015).

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Market conditions favour sustainable agro-biodiversity production

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: ABD friendly agro-enterprises generate sustainable income of at least 20% more than the current baseline by 2014.

baseline.comment: Agro-enterprises are small-scale, localized and seasonal, with negligible access to international or national markets and business opportunities

target.comment: Sustainable national or international value chains developed for at least one organic environmentally-friendly ADB product in each of 4 project areas and improvements in local livelihoods demonstrated.

actual.comment:
In 2014-2015 the project continued follow-up activities aimed at strengthening the success in entering foreign markets and increasing incomes from selling agrobiodiversity certified products.
The income of 61 locals (including 8 women) and households has increased by 15% due to participation in the Small Grants Program.
Within the frameworks of the Micro-Loan Funds activities, USD 20,000 were distributed among 48 farmers, including 24 women, for rehabilitating and creating gardens, cultivating cereal crops and running agribusiness. Development of organic farming and cultivation of forage grasses (alfalfa, sainfoin, barley) provides additional income and guarantees repayment of loans and additional financial benefits. The working assets of the Micro-Loan Fund were replenished by USD 25,000.
Farmers’ technical capacity has strengthened as well. In particular, more than 100 solar dryers were manufactured and distributed in 8 jamoats for processing agrobiodiversity products as those solar dryers were in great demand among the locals due to low production losses. The results of the follow-up monitoring and questionings indicate that because of using solar dryers the loss of agrobiodiversity products reduced by 60% and the income of farmers increased by 30%.
Totally, over the years of implementation the project contributed to establishing a number of successful agrobiodiversity-friendly agro-enterprises including both processing facilities and solar dryers (which annually support not less than 20 farms in delivery of agrobiodiversity dry products to local markets). By the project completion date, all such enterprises generate sustainable income.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Value chains of ABD-friendly products in domestic market
Favourable conditions exist for access to overseas markets.

baseline.comment: Non-existent and/or unorganized marketing of local ABD goods to national and international markets

target.comment: Up to four (fruit and nuts) agrobiodiversity certified and/or non-certified products marketed and sold in new national and/or international markets.

actual.comment:
In 2014-2015 the project continued its interventions aimed at improving access to local markets and building capacities of local farmers and manufacturers of agrobiodiversity products.
35 farmers and agro-enterpreneurs from the project areas become capacitated in methods of domestic and international certification, that now allows them to demonstrate the benefits of agribusiness.
Small Grants Program and the Micro-Loan Fund have strengthened local business capacities. Specifically, successful use of grants and microloans contributed to strengthening the components needed for processing agrobiodiversity products. It also served as the basis for building confidence between participants of the horizontal part of the price chain.
Collaboration with the Pamir-Travel LLC continued and the following package of certified and properly packaged agrobiodiversity products was produced (mulberry bars) and sold in national and international markets. To that, the quality certificate continues promoting the demand for this product both at local and international markets.
As in previous years, certified products of the project receive national and international recognition and being regularly presented at various meetings and conferences. For instance, certified mulberry products were presented at the concurrent events of the 12th Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea, and during the High-level International Conference on the implementation of the International Decade for Action "Water for Life" in Dushanbe, where they become very popular with the participants to the mentioned events.
In the final analysis, one of the main achievements became the increased interest of farmers in presenting certified agrobiodiversity products at local and foreign markets. This, in turn, contributed to the enrichment of markets with own ecologically pure and competitive agrobiodiversity products. Nationally produced agrobiodiversity products are currently available at both national and international markets, and the approach, embedded by the project, provides for the sustainability of those achievements.

result.title: Goal
result.description: Reduction of GHG emissions from energy use by rural and remote communities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Avoided annual GHG emissions from rural communities’ energy use by end of project (EOP), ktCO2/year
Avoided GHG emissions from rural communities’ energy use by end of project influence period, 10 years (EOPIP), ktCO2

target.comment:
45 ktCO2
244 ktCO2

actual.comment:
1.84 ktCO2
18.4 ktCO2

result.title: Objective
result.description: Significantly accelerate the development of small-scale hydropower (SHP) by removing barriers through enabling legal and regulatory framework, capacity building and developing sustainable delivery models, thus substantially avoiding the use of conventional biomass and fossil fuels for power and other energy needs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of new small hydropower projects under implementation by EOP
Minimum No. of fully operational sHPPs by EOP
Annual electricity generation from newly installed sHPPs by EOP, MWh/yr
Cumulative electricity generation from newly installed SHPs by EOPIP, MWh/yr

actual.comment:
1 small hydropower plant with 30 kW of installed capacity is constructed and commissioned in Sorvo vilalge of Vahdat district. Total of 3 SHPPs with cumulative capacity of 245 kW are constructed and commissioned from the beginning of the project.
Manufacturing and construction of 4 small hydropower plants started. The total cumulative capacity of the foreseen plants is 475 kW.
1,288 MW/h/year
N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: No. of operational demo/pilot SHP plants by EOP

actual.comment:
Total of 3 SHPPs have been constructed and commissioned, while 4 more SHPPs are in pipeline.
The total cumulative capacity of the constructed and commissioned SHPPs is 245 kW that annually generate 1,288 MW/h/year.
The 4 additional SHPPs that are in the pipeline will have a total cumulative installed capacity of 475 kW able to generate 2,460 MW/h/year of electricity.

baseline.comment: N/a

target.comment: Conference on integrated rewable-energy based rural development organized by the end of Year 4

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Adapted and enhanced legislative and regulatory framework for small-scale hydropower development in the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Adopted regulation operationalizing RES Law

baseline.comment: No regulations in support of RES Law

target.comment: Rules and regulations adopted by end of Year 1

actual.comment:
The legislative and regulatory frameworks for small scale hydropower development created in the previous years with the project’s support, the law on Renewable Energy Sources and the law on Energy efficiency and energy saving, have led the Government to adoption of strategic documents in favor of renewable energy development. As such the national programme for small hydropower plants construction was revised, and the national strategy for the development of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency is being developed. The revised national programme that will cover the period of 2015-2020 will include the small hydro, solar and wind energy sources, and during the reporting period the programme is being adopted.
Adopted sub-laws to the law on Renewable Energy Sources also regulate the conditions for the solar and wind energy sources, although the project does not directly aim at development of these sources. Nevertheless, the latest developments of renewables in the country suggest that combined application of renewable sources along with small hydropower would better address the issues with the lack of energy in the rural communities. The project has therefore been effective in communicating this message to the government, which was endorsed.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced technical and planning know-how and developed market chain for SHP in Tajikistan

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of the total SHP installed cost provided by locally made goods and services

target.comment: 50% by the end of Year 4

actual.comment:
In line with the developed regulations for SHP development, the capacities to produce, maintain and operate SHPPs were created through the transfer of technology to beneficiary companies, Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi, and through educating students at the Technical universities in Dushanbe and Kurgantyube. The local manufacturers’ supported by the project have produced, tested and installed portable turbines, where the share of locally produced goods and services is estimated at over 50%. The companies are now engaged in the production and installation of electromechanical equipment for additional 4 SHPPs.
The human capacity of the technicians and experts in SHPP development and management is being built through the project. Annually, a total of 100 students from the technical universities are taking SHPP courses based on the modules developed with the project’s support.. To date 300 students have been reported to have received these courses at the Tajik Technical University and Kurgantyube Energy Institute.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Improved confidence on the technical and economic viability of integrated SHP-based rural development model

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No. of SHP demos/pilots incorporating aspects of productive uses and livelihood support for host communities

target.comment: At least 5 community-owned SHP projects operate on a sustainable basis and at least 5 additional are under construction by the end of Year 4

actual.comment: Total of 3 community-owned SHPPs (Nurofar, Yazghulam and Sorvo) are operating on sustainable basis and 4 more are under construction. Sustainability of the constructed SHPPs is ensured through the introduced management mechanisms, fee collection methods, capacity building of the operators through trainings and provision of basic equipment. Additionally, SHPP Nurofar sells excess electricity to the local businesses (fuel station, dairy shop and the plastic windows production workshop) during the summer time based on contractual agreement. This measure allows the SHPP to operate on sustainable basis, as well as allowing the local businesses to have savings from the electricity bills. The national tariff for businesses is 33 dirams per kW (0.05 USD) whereas the SHPP offers a trade off electricity for 25 dirams per kW (0.038 USD).

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: National Scaling-up Programme of Renewable Energy-based Integrated Rural Development

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program

baseline.comment: N/a

target.comment: Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program by the end of Year 4

actual.comment:
Through continuous dialogue and political advice rendered to the government counterparts by the project and the international community operating in the energy sector, the Government has and is adopting a number of strategies in the energy sector, one of which is the National Strategy for Renewable Energy and corresponding action plans and national programmes. The programme and the strategies aim at scaling-up renewable energy based integrated rural development.
For instance, the government has already provided direct investments for SHP construction. In 2012 -2014 the amount invested by the Government cumulatively constituted USD 4.4 mln for 5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW. This investment has resulted in covering 1,500 households, schools, hospitals, as well as the business facilities and created employment for 200 people in remote rural areas of the country.

result.title: Output 1.1
result.description: Formulated, approved and enforced implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) of the new Law for RES that will facilitate actions geared towards the enhancement of the market environment for SHP

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Simplified procedures and principles for the licensing and construction of SHP facilities
National RE/EE Fund

baseline.comment:
RES Law includes a number of provisions to facilitate investment in grid-connected RE projects, but they are not operationalized
National RE/EE Fund

target.comment:
Procedures adopted and enforced by end of Year 1
National RE/EE Fund set-up and is operational by end of Year 2

actual.comment:
A permanent inter-institutional working group for the implementation of the law "on energy saving and energy efficiency" and elaboration of proposals to implement the law has been established. Inter-institutional working group has 3 sub-groups responsible for: (i) issues related to establishment of Trust Fund for RES and EE; (ii) development of the National Strategy on RES and National energy saving program; and (iii) development of legal acts. The group is chaired by the Ministry of energy and water resources.
The charter of the Trust Fund has been revised to best meet the current developments in the renewable energy sector and was endorsed by 5 ministries except for the Ministry of Finance. The financial part of the trust fund still remains unresolved due to the lack of financial commitments from the main international institutions operating in the country that were considered as the primary source of funds along with the national contributions. It has to be mentioned however that the share of the national contribution remains unknown and requires further discussions.

result.title: Output 1.2
result.description: Central and local government institutions with enhanced capacities to develop and coordinate SHP projects.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # staff members from relevant central and local government institutions trained in developing and coordinating SHP projects

target.comment: 30 staff members trained by the end of Year 2

actual.comment: In addition to the trainings carried out by the project for the Government representatives during the previous reporting year, the capacity assessment of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources staff was conducted. It has been revealed that there is a significant gap in the planning of RES projects, especially in the financial and economic analysis of the SHPP projects, which creates a barrier for adequately managing and coordinating resources expanded for the construction of SHPPs. In this regard, the project in cooperation with EU Sustainable Energy Programme for Central Asia (CASEP), and direct involvement of the project’s Chief Technical Adviser, organized 3-days trainings on “Creating and managing the SHPP cadastre”, “Business game: Practical development of RES projects” and “Financial and economic analysis of SHPP projects” which have helped to increase the capacity of 45 staff of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources and Barki Tojik (the national electricity utility company).

result.title: Output 2.1
result.description: Guidebook on technical and policy aspects of SHP project development (to be used in all trainings to be delivered by the project)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Guidebook on SHP project development

target.comment: Guidebook on SHP project development prepared and disseminated by the end of Year 1

actual.comment: Completed

result.title: Output 2.2
result.description: Local workshops and manufacturers with enhanced capacities to install, construct, manufacture and repair SHP system equipment and components

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared for selected local manufacturers

target.comment: 2 technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared by the end of Year 1

actual.comment:
The capacities of the local manufacturers (Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi) to design, manufacture, construct, install and repair the SHP systems are further enhanced. The local manufacturers have received additional sets of needed equipment for the production of the SHPPs that include electronic and mechanical tools and equipment.
Under the supervision and direct coaching of the technology transfer deliverer, the local manufacturers have mastered the production of the portable turbines (2 x 15 kW) that were installed and commissioned on a pilot basis. Based on this experience, the manufacturers have been prepared for the manufacturing, construction, installation and repair of larger electromechanical equipment for SHPPs. Both manufacturers are now able to produce turbines and set into operation SHPPs of ranging capacities from 1 kW to 1,000 kW.

result.title: Output 2.3
result.description: Vocational training program for technicians involved in SHP design/construction and O&M

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP

target.comment: 20 technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP starting from Year 2

actual.comment:
The project has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Tajik-Technical University to provide vocational trainings to technicians involved in SHP production. Based on the signed MoU the project has helped the university in developing the vocational training modules and provided IT equipment (a laptop, overhead projector and a screen). In August 2014, 3-day vocational trainings for 18 technicians from Vahdat district and 7 representatives of the Ministries of Energy of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan were held. The practical trainings were carried out on the facilities of Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi with which the University has agreements..
In September 2014, the OSCE office in Dushanbe has requested the services of the University to educate 15 technicians in Rasht valley.

result.title: Output 2.4
result.description: Local manufacturers capable of producing combined electric and biomass-fired heating and cooking devices for rural households

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of local craft workshops capable of manufacturing and assemblage of simple, efficient and low-cost electric heating and cooking devices

target.comment: At least 1 local craft workshops by the end of Year 3

actual.comment: A Project study on the viability of producing the combined electrical and biomass fired heating and cooking device indicates that production of the devices locally will not be sustained: a) Local power supplies of 1 kW will not be sufficient to operate the device reducing its demand; and b) limited demand for these devices is expected due to the flooding of less expensive Chinese goods. The target is to be cancelled based on the recommendations of the Mid-Term Review.

result.title: Output 3.1
result.description: Technical studies, political commitments and institutional framework secured for pilot SHP projects

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Feasibility studies
Number of integrated district development
Number of SHP projects in the pipeline

target.comment: FS for 2 sites by end of Year 1, 3 sites - by end of Year 2, 5 sites - by end of Year 3. IDDP for 2 districts by end of Year 2, 3 districts - by end of Year 3, At least 5 further SHP projects identified and construction started (without direct project support)

actual.comment:
The feasibility studies have been completed in the previous reporting period.
The IDDPs for 5 districts have been reviewed and updated accordingly.
5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW was constructed by the Government. Additionally, OSCE has supported the construction of 2 micro SHPPs (10 kW each) in Rasht Valley. IFC has signed an agreement with the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources for the construction of 18 MW hydropower plant in Zervashan valley. The Japan Government funded “Livelihoods Improvement in Tajikistan-Afghanistan Cross border Areas” (LITACA) project implemented by UNDP finances construction of 2 SHPPs in Shurabad and Jilikul districts. The electromechanical equipment for these two SHPPs (175 kW and 100 kW) will be produced by the local manufacturers supported by the project.

result.title: Output 3.3
result.description: Pilot SHP operations sustained

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of PPAs signed for purchase of power from pilot SHP plants by EOP
Number of local business supported in pilot localities

target.comment: At least 2 by the end of Year and 5 by the end of Year 4

actual.comment: The operation of the two commissioned pilot SHPPs in Burunov and Yazghulom are sustained by regular monitoring and provided technical support to the operators responsible for the operation-maintenance and management of the plants. The operators of these plants have been educated through the vocational trainings and have been supplied with the maintenance tools and equipment. The SHPP in Yazghulam that provides electricity to the border outpost on the Tajik-Afghan border is sustained by the technicians serving in the border post. The plant in Burunov on the other hand provides electricity to a number of clients including the households and the social and economic facilities, and has been connected to the national grid. Both SHPPs are operating in a sustainable manner.

result.title: Output 4.1
result.description: Project results asessed, analyzed and compiled into comprehensive national report

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Project results and Lessons learnt report

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: Project results and Lessons learnt report prepared by end of Year 4

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Output 4.3
result.description: Approved and funded proposal for national scaling up of the SHP demos/pilots

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Annual amount of governmental incentives allocated to support investment in new SHP plants under the scale-up plan by EOP, in USD

actual.comment: Considering the recommendations and policy advice of the project, in 2012 – 2014 the Government has provided direct investments in SHPPs construction that cumulatively constitutes USD 4.4 mln for 5 SHPPs. The total capacity of the commissioned SHPPs is 1,967 kW.
